Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2017, International Cryptology Conference (CRYPTO17)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal supports 15-20 students for their travel to attend the 2017 Annual International Cryptology Conference (CRYPTO), sponsored by IACR (International Association of Cryptologic Research), in cooperation with the Computer Science Department of the University of California, Santa Barbara. CRYPTO is a highly selective conference in cryptography, attracting students, researchers and industry specialists from all over the world. The scope of research papers accepted to CRYPTO range from the theoretical foundations of cryptology to application and implementation of cryptographic schemes. As such, it fits closely with the goals of NSF's Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) program, which include applied cryptography and implementation of cryptographic schemes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As a branch in mathematics and computer science, cryptology has been an active research field for several decades. With the rapid development of computing and networking technologies, advances in cryptologyhave become increasingly important with respect to both academic research and industry applications. Such research advances, together with their applications to computer and network security, serve as the foundation to secure today’s connected digital world. CRYPTO is the Annual International Cryptology Conference, sponsored by IACR (International Association of Cryptologic Research), in cooperation with the Computer Science Department of the University of California, Santa Barbara. The first CRYPTO was held in 1981,
and since then CRYPTO has been IACR’s flagship conference, attracting researchers in the field of cryp-tology from all over the world. The scope of research papers accepted to CRYPTO range from theoretical
foundation of cryptology to application and implementation of cryptographic schemes. In 2017 we had over 400 participants.

This projected provided student scholarships to ease or eliminate the financial costs of attending CRYPTO. Awards were given to students with an emphasis put on awarding NSF funded scholarships to undergraduates and historically under-represented groups in computing. The NSF funded 4 students for the full cost of their conference, including travel, housing and registration (3 undergraduate and 1 Phd Student), 9 students with funding for their housing costs while at the conference, and  11 students with the costs of their reigstration.
